articles.title: OCTOBER 1988
articles.summary: This document outlines a detailed schedule of astronomical events and club activities for October 1988, with a preview into November. Key events include multiple 'Mars Watch' observing sessions at Branham Lane City Park, star parties at Fremont Peak and Grant Ranch County Parks, and a presentation by Ernie Piini on a solar eclipse over Borneo. The schedule also features board meetings, the conclusion of an introductory observational astronomy class, and an upcoming talk on Lick Observatory's telescope maker.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article announces an upcoming report by Ernie Piini, detailing his experience observing the March 18th total solar eclipse from Borneo. This presentation, titled "Eclipse Over Borneo," will cover his latest observations and insights from the event.

articles.title: ENTERTAINMENT STYLE ALWAYS INSURE US OF A WONDERFUL EVENING. DON'T MISS IT!
articles.summary: An entertainment event titled "ENTERTAINMENT STYLE ALWAYS INSURE US OF A WONDERFUL EVENING. DON'T MISS IT!" is scheduled for October 1st at 8 pm. The event will take place at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building.

articles.title: SWAP MEET AND SLIDE/EQUIPMENT NIGHT
articles.summary: A club swap meet was successful, generating $110, suggesting its continuation. This was followed by a slide and equipment presentation featuring various telescopes and slides. The highlight was John Briggs' ongoing research into early telescopes, specifically those built by C.A. Robert Lundin, a former Clark employee, which included displaying memorabilia and drawings from Alvan Clark obtained from Lundin's daughter.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY AND TELESCOPE MAKING MAGAZINES
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is facilitating group rate renewals for Astronomy and Telescope Making magazines, with a deadline at the end of the November 5 General Meeting. Subscribers can renew for one year at discounted rates ($14 for Astronomy, $8 for Telescope Making) by sending a check to Jim Van Nuland, with specific instructions for new subscriptions or converting independent subscriptions expiring in 1989.

articles.title: MARS WATCH - 88
articles.summary: The SJAA is continuing its "MARS WATCH '88" series of public star parties at Branham Lane park. Members are encouraged to attend and showcase Mars, which is currently at its best viewing, to the public.

articles.title: PERSEID METEOR SHOWER
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland reported on a successful observation of the Perseid Meteor Shower at Fremont Peak on August 11-12. Despite initial fog and high humidity, the sky cleared, offering a rewarding show with an estimated rate of at least one meteor per minute, peaking on the 12th. The report highlights the shower's reliability and good observability.

articles.title: BY: BRIAN ZEHRING
articles.summary: The author recounts an observing trip to "the Peak," starting with a view of the Sun through a hydrogen-alpha filter and a talk on Mars. The night progressed with observations of deep-sky objects, including the Lagoon Nebula, Andromeda Galaxy, and the Ring Nebula, using a 30-inch telescope. The session was eventually cut short around 3 AM due to heavy fog and dew.

articles.title: CLUB OBSERVATORY
articles.summary: The club has been fundraising for approximately eight years to build an observatory and now possesses sufficient funds. They are actively seeking a suitable site, exploring Mt. Uminum, a former star party location, and are currently in discussions with the Mid-peninsula Open Space District regarding property rights near an old Air Force radar station.

articles.title: AN OVERVIEW OF OBSERVING SITES
articles.summary: This article is the final installment of a series by Don Machholz and Rich Page, summarizing their two-year effort to identify and evaluate potential astronomical observing sites in the Bay Area. They detail their methodology, which included daytime scouting, light pollution checks, and interviews, ultimately reporting on 15 sites across 14 articles. The authors also provide updates on previously reviewed locations, correct elevation data, and list several sites considered unsuitable with explanations for their exclusion.

articles.title: Mt. Diablo State Park
articles.summary: This article reviews Mt. Diablo State Park, concluding it's not ideal for San Jose Astronomical Association members due to distance, locked gates, and light pollution. It also briefly mentions other observing locations like Twin Creeks (deemed unsuitable), Brickyard, Uvas Reservoir parking lot, and San Felipe Road (noted for dark skies). The piece marks the end of a series of site reviews, with the author thanking contributors and hoping readers find a favorite observing spot.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: The article is a collection of classified advertisements primarily featuring used astronomical equipment for sale, including various Celestron C8 models, a Meade 2080, a Bausch & Lomb 60mm telescope, and a Sky & Telescope magazine collection. Additionally, it advertises an employment opportunity for an optical systems engineer at Finial Technology.

articles.title: COMING: GRAZING OCCULTATION EXPEDITION BY JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland is leading a grazing occultation expedition of Regulus across the Bay Area and Central Valley on Wednesday morning, November 30. The article explains that observers within a narrow zone will see Regulus disappear and reappear multiple times due to the Moon's irregular limb, allowing for precise mapping of the lunar profile. Participants are instructed on the observation process, which involves recording events against a WWV time signal, and are encouraged to attend an upcoming talk for more details.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article provides an update on observations of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), noting its recent early recovery and describing its current appearance, including the easily visible Red Spot Hollow. It contrasts present visibility with past decades, highlighting historical observations and the GRS's erratic movement. The author also offers practical advice for amateur astronomers on how to observe the GRS, detailing necessary equipment, techniques, and filters to enhance viewing.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PST
articles.summary: This document provides a comprehensive schedule detailing the predicted transit times of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) across the celestial meridian. Presented in Pacific Standard Time (PST), the table lists specific dates and times from early October through early November, enabling astronomers and enthusiasts to plan their observation sessions. The information appears to be a helpful guide for visual observation of this prominent Jovian feature.

articles.title: BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: NASA's Space Shuttle launch, previously expected between September 26 and October 3, has been delayed from its planned September 14 date due to Hurricane Gilbert, despite earlier technical issues with a leaky fuel line being resolved. Meanwhile, a pact regarding the Space Station is reported to be ready for signing.

articles.title: SOVIET SPACE PROGRAM
articles.summary: One Soviet spacecraft en route to Mars may have been lost due to a ground control error causing it to lose its antenna lock on Earth and begin tumbling, while its companion spacecraft, still under control, carries a Phobos lander and a mobile hopper. Separately, a Soyuz-TM spacecraft successfully landed on its third attempt on September 7th, returning two cosmonauts from the Mir space station after experiencing multiple re-entry failures due to sensor and computer errors.

articles.title: CONTRACTOR FOR AXAF SELECTED
articles.summary: NASA has selected TRW as the contractor to develop the Advanced X-ray Astrophysics Facility (AXAF). This facility is the fourth in the great observatory series and is targeted for a mid-1996 launch.

articles.title: SPACEHAB SIGNS AGREEMENT WITH NASA
articles.summary: Spacehab has signed an agreement with NASA, securing six partial space shuttle flights starting in 1991. The Spacehab module provides increased pressurized space in the shuttle's payload bay, accessible by astronauts for storage and experiments.

articles.title: DOUBLE, TRIPPLE AND MULTIPLE STARS BY: PATRICK DONNELLY
articles.summary: This article provides an observational guide to double, triple, and multiple star systems within the constellation Lyra, particularly well-placed for viewing in early autumn. It details prominent examples such as Epsilon Lyrae (the "double-double"), Zeta Lyrae, Delta Lyrae, Beta Lyrae, and 8-Lyrae. For each system, the article describes its components, magnitudes, separations, and the optical aid required for resolution, encouraging amateur astronomers to explore these fascinating stellar configurations.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz provides updates on several comets, noting the uncertain fate of Comet Machholz (1988j) as it approaches the sun, and reporting the recovery of Periodic Comets Churyumov-Gerasimenko (1988i) and Kopff (1988k). He also suggests viewing the Ring Nebula (M-57) as an accessible target for stargazers after observing other celestial objects.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This document provides ephemerides for Periodic Comet Tempel 2 (1987g) and Comet Machholz (1988j), detailing their Right Ascension, Declination, Elongation, and Magnitude from late September to mid-November. It includes notes on their visibility, movement relative to the sun and Earth, and predicted observational challenges or opportunities for amateur astronomers.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article explains the process of recovering periodic comets after they recede from the inner solar system and dim, detailing how professional astronomers utilize large telescopes, photographic film, or CCDs to locate them after aphelion. It describes the technical steps for official recovery, including motion tracking and temporary designations, and highlights instances of both professional and occasional amateur visual recoveries. The piece also mentions specific astronomers and observatories involved in this specialized astronomical work.

articles.title: OFFICERS
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers of an organization, detailing their respective roles such as President, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer, and Editor. Each officer's name is provided along with their contact phone number.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS
articles.summary: This document provides a directory of an organization's Board of Directors, listing the names of its members along with their respective phone numbers. It functions as a contact list for key personnel, though one member's phone number is not listed.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership types and their respective costs, including 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T' (likely referring to Sky & Telescope magazine), and 'Junior (Under 18)'. The form also provides instructions for submission, including a mailing address for the treasurer and contact information.
